subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify evidence based pedagogical practices implemented by high-quality educators.
Review and analyze lesson plan criteria to identify and define the components of a successful lesson plan.
Critique lesson objectives for specificity, measurability, and alignment.
Evaluate lesson plans, pedagogy, and assessments using several quality measures.
Justify a self-assessment of professional dispositions of educators.
Reflect on personal growth in the areas of lesson planning, formative assessment, and pedagogical effectiveness.
Evaluate avenues for building a virtual professional learning network.

sections.title: EDC 801 - Special Education Law
text: Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken EDUC 951 .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Examine and analyze federal law, state law, and administrative rules pertaining to students with disabilities for required assessments and qualified examiners by disability type for the evaluation of students with disabilities as part of assessment related to the special education process.
Summarize and discuss the key procedures and timelines for the referral, evaluations, and determination of eligibility for special education and related services.

Interpret the rights and responsibilities of schools, students, families, teachers, and other professionals related to the identification, placement, and service of students with disabilities in accordance with the New Hampshire Procedural Safeguards.
Explain the concept of the least restrictive environment and the continuum of educational environments.
Examine and discuss the manifestation determination process and significant case law involving behavior.
Research and summarize the continuum of approaches to dispute resolution in special education.
Research and compose a parent-friendly guide to IDEA requirements around discipline and suspension.

sections.title: EDC 802 - Young Children with Exceptionalities, Birth to Age 8

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Research, describe, and compare typical and non-typical development of children, birth through age eight.

Examine Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) Part C (ages 0-through age 2) B and Part B (ages 3 to 21) and delineate the implications for the education of children with disabilities, birth through age eight.
Research and evaluate the history of special education in the United States, changing views of disability, and the planning and delivery of special education services with an emphasis on inclusion.
Analyze and evaluate the significant issues in the education of linguistically and culturally diverse students and students who are gifted.

Categorize and synthesize the research on the manifestations, origins, and teaching implications for the following: a. motor development b. medically-related problems c. adaptive behavior and self-help skills d. social and emotional development e. communication and language development f. cognitive development
Describe and evaluate the assessment tools used to identify the disabilities listed above.
Reflect on best practices for children with disabilities through written assignments and through selection of work samples for their professional portfolio.

sections.title: EDC 803 - The Dynamic Role of the Special Educator
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken EDUC 901C .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Explore the college's digital library.
Introduce the American Psychological Association annotation and format requirements.
Provide a beginning teacher with an organizational framework for the varying roles of a special education teacher.
Provide an in-depth understanding of their case management responsibilities.

sections.title: EDC 804 - Assessment of Young Children in EC/ECSPED - Birth to Age 8
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Examine assessment tools (to measure intelligence, communication skills, academic skills, and other skills) typically used to assess young children in his/her district and discuss these tools with a qualified examiner.

Examine relevant formal and informal assessments from following list and administer as appropriate: a. classroom observation b. an early learning profile/scale c. criterion-referenced test d. a functional behavior assessment e. an assessment portfolio f. an adaptive behavior assessment g. a comprehensive standardized achievement battery

Participate as a member of an education team to identify, interpret, present, and discuss appropriate assessments to: a. determine eligibility for special education b. develop the Individualized Education Plan/Individualized Family Support Plan c. plan instruction d. evaluate progress f. communicate educational results to others.
Synthesize available information and incorporate into assessment process.
Eexamine developmental variations that are physical, sensory, cognitive, and emotional and the implications of these developmental variations for the entire assessment process.

Reflect on best practices and the legal and ethical responsibilities of a special education teacher in early childhood settings through written assignments and through selection of work samples for professional portfolios.

sections.title: EDC 805 - Collaboration, Consultation and Teaming In Early Childhood & Early Childhood Special Education
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Explore the roles and responsibilities of early care and education professionals and families of young children with exceptionalities.
Identify and evaluate models which support the collaborative efforts of early care and education professionals and families of young children with exceptionalities.
Identify roles and responsibilities of early care and education professionals and families in the special education process.
Develop, implement, and evaluate a model for collaboration to support the development and learning of young children with exceptionalities.
Select an assignment and critically reflect on best practice in collaborative partnerships to add to their professional portfolio.

sections.title: EDC 806 - IFSP, IEP, and Transition Plans, Birth to Age 8
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify, research, and evaluate the legal/ethical considerations and implications in the development of an IFSP and an IEP.
Identify, research, and evaluate the critical elements and importance of early childhood transition plans.

Develop and evaluate both an IFSP and an IEP which meet the following criteria: a. meets all legal requirements b. provides access to the general curriculum c. identifies services to support all aspects and stages of childs/students development d. delineates roles and responsibilities and embeds an accountability process for family, school and community partners

sections.title: EDC 807 - Behavior Interventions for Young Children
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Examine life skills, e.g. attachment, affiliation, self regulation, initiative, problem solving and respect that children need as foundation for the development of positive social skills.
Identify and implement methods to promote positive interpersonal relationships for children in early intervention, preschool programs or classroom environments.
Examine and propose strategies to manage difficult behaviors.
Research the relationship/correspondence between planning for successful instruction and effective behavior management plans.
Develop and evaluate behavior incentive plans and report on applying time out effectively.
Reflect on best practices in early childhood special education through written assignments, and through selection of work samples for their professional portfolio.

sections.title: EDC 808 - Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics in Early Childhood and Early Child Spec. Ed. 0-8
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: The rational for integration of the STEM curriculum and its impact on learning.
Use problem-solving approaches to investigate and understand mathematics content.
Reflect on best practices in early childhood special education through written assignments, and through selection of work samples for professional portfolios.
Use technology to identify developmentally appropriate uses of online resources.
Enter artifacts into the TaskStream e-portfolio demonstrating attained skills.
Understand curriculum, assessment and instruction through 49 hours of clinical observation.

sections.title: EDC 809 - Teaching Language Arts and Literacy in Early Childhood and Early Childhood Special Education
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Demonstrate an understanding development of language and communication in infancy, toddler, preschool children and older young children.
Understand the complexity of learning to communicate and read and the many factors that affect the process.
Demonstrate an understanding of various theories and levels of development in emerging literacy including spelling, reading and writing.
Demonstrate knowledge of phonological awareness, concepts of print, and phonemic awareness.
Demonstrate knowledge of word recognition skills and the various ways to teach phonics.
Demonstrate knowledge of various assisted reading approaches to foster reading fluency.
Develop an appreciation for how literature, including storytelling, poetry, drama, puppetry, can effectively encourage reading and writing skills.
Develop skills in ongoing assessment and understand the differences in individual development.
Explore appropriate early childhood approaches and programs components for effective literacy development.
Understand the parent-teacher partnership and identify ways in which parents can strengthen a child's language and literacy growth.
Enter artifacts into electronic portfolio demonstrating attained skills.

sections.title: EDC 810 - Curriculum, Assessment & Instruction in Early Childhood and Early Childhood Spec Educ. Birth-Age 8
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Examine, develop, and evaluate developmentally appropriate curriculum and instruction that meets children needs and allows them to reach their potential in the following areas: a. adaptive development b. approaches to learning c. cognitive development d. creative expression/aesthetic development e. communication and literacy development f. health and safety g. moral development h. physical development i. social/emotional development.

Identify, design, and promote individualized supports, strategies, accommodations, and modifications that meet children educational needs in the following areas: a. approaches to learning b. cognitive development c. creative expression/aesthetic development d. communication and literacy development e. health and safety f. moral development g. physical development h. social/emotional development.

Identify and evaluate developmentally appropriate curricula, instructional objectives, and instructional strategies, based upon formal and informal assessments, and the New Hampshire Early Learning Guidelines and to include: a. approaches to learning b. cognitive development c. creative expression/aesthetic development d. communication and literacy development e. health and safety f. moral development g. physical development h. social/emotional development.
Reflect on best practices in early childhood special education through written assignments and through selection of work samples for professional portfolios.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Reflect upon the foundations of special education changing views of disability, and the planning and delivery of special education services.

Identify and summarize cognitive, physical, sensory, behavioral, and social-emotional characteristics of and adaptive behaviors associated with specific disabilities as defined under IDEA, and how they impact learning and daily living.

Apply the principles of Universal Design for Learning and identify strategies in the areas of multiple means of representation, action and expression and engagement, to support inclusion of students with disabilities in the general education classroom.

Identify and summarize instructional strategies, accommodations, modifications, interventions, and evidence-based practices to support the inclusion of students with disabilities in the classroom and the community.
Give examples of assistive technologies to support learners with disabilities.
Create a resource of systems of support, including related service providers and disability-related resources for each of the IDEA disabilities.
Develop a reference guide on the stages of human development from birth-18 years and the implications of disability.

sections.title: EDC 817 - Positive Behavior Guidance and Student Engagement
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: DEVELOP a Classroom Behavior Management plan based on a specific age/grade.
CONDUCT Functional Behavioral Assessment (FBA) and develop Behavior Intervention Plan (BIP).
TEACH foundational skills in math or English Language Arts.

Collaborate with school personnel to discuss and summarize school-wide positive behavior interventions and supports (SWPBIS), policies and assessments that implement techniques to enhance motivation and learning.
Recognize the interaction between behavior management and planning for effective instruction.
Identify and use technology tools for data collection and classroom management.
Complete 55-60 clinical hours in a K-12 environment.

sections.title: EDC 818 - Transition Planning and Developing IEPs
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Review NH Law as it relates to the responsibilities of a special education teacher.
Summarize the legal, ethical and effective practices for a successful IEP.
Learn to write measurable goals and determine data based progress monitoring.
Compare the IFSP and IEP process (timelines, team participants, and required components, including transitions.
Collaborate to develop a professional quality Transition Plan/IEP for each case study student that conforms to IDEA 2004 standards.
Understand the intent of the new regulations in IDEA 2004 regarding transitioning.

sections.title: EDC 819 - Using Technology to Teach Social Studies
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken EDUC 803M .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Develop units that reflect district and state GLEs for social studies (grades K- 8) that include lessons that focus on at least two of the following Five Content Strands from the NH Curriculum Framework for Social Studies: (a) Civics (b) Economics (c) Geography (d) New Hampshire and United States History (e) World History and Contemporary Issues (f) Note: An elementary education teacher is expected to be able to explain the following (NH Standard 612.04) (g) World geography and its effects on human, physical, political and economic systems (h) Pre-history and early civilizations to those of the current day, including their developments and Transformations (i) US history from European exploration and colonization to current developments and (j) Transformations (k) The nature and purpose, and forms of local, state, national and international governments (l) Basic micro- and macro economics
Demonstrate a working knowledge of the tools, goals, and areas of study in anthropology, sociology, and psychology.

Using a constructivist approach to teaching social studies, develop, plan and teach a 10 lesson unit that addresses District Standards for their respective grade level, and, the NH State Curriculum Frameworks Grade Level Equivalencies (GLEs) for Social Studies and the Arts. Five of these lessons need to incorporate as teaching tools, at least two different forms of the following technology into the first five lessons: PowerPoint, wiki, blogs, social networks, bookmarking utilities, message boards and web-based videos. Five lessons must demonstrate pupil use of at least one form of technology (excluding word processing) and incorporate the Arts into student outcomes and evaluation.
Demonstrate appropriate lesson adaptations and modification for identified students with special needs.
Discuss legal and ethical issues in the use of educational technology and compare implications from different learning theories in order to successfully integrate technology into the classroom.

Use and evaluate various software and web-based programs that may increase both student and teacher productivity: bookmarking utilities, message boards, social networking websites, web-based video-sharing sites, Instant Messengers and Blogs.
Participate within professional learning communities via web-based technologies.
Become familiar with the foundations for effective technology integration in the classroom and develop a plan to integrate existing and new technologies into the classroom.
Identify the national, state and local standards for technology that will be covered within individual grade level classrooms.
Write a research paper that addresses the legal, ethical and cultural issues to consider when integrating educational technology into K through 12 schools.
Enter artifacts into the Task-Stream e-portfolio system demonstrating attained skills.

sections.title: EDC 820 - Instructional Methods, Strategies and Technologies to Meet the Needs of All Students
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken EDUC 851A , EDUC 851B .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Understand the foundations of learning and instruction.
Develop skills for planning and monitoring performance.

Using the K-12 student achievement data, will assess, teach, monitor progress and evaluate instructional strategies for a student in three of the following areas: math, reading, written expression, vocabulary (content), and social emotional /behavioral skills.
Develop at least ten lessons to address the area noted above.
Understand the Direct Instructional Method and apply this method to lessons.
Know when and how to use the Concept Teaching Method and apply this method to lessons.
Understand Problem Based Learning instruction.
Teach specific strategies to enhance student engagement or learning.
Be able to assess a student's level of understanding in mathematics.
Demonstrate discussion/discourse skills including the control of questioning and wait time in lessons.
Demonstrate an understanding of social/emotional development and how to teach skills in this area.
Write a research paper on the effectiveness of strategy based learning (activating cognition/metacognition) to improve educational outcomes for students.

sections.title: EDC 821 - Assessment of Students with Disabilities
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken EDUC 939, EDUC 940.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Reflect upon the legal and ethical responsibilities of a special education teacher.
Understand the basic terminology and scores in assessment.
Discuss with a qualified examiner the assessment tools typically used to measure intelligence, communication skills, academic skills, and other skills.
Understand evaluation team membership and how the above areas can affect academic learning.
Administer and interpret informal assessments including observations, criterion-referenced tests, functional behavior assessment, portfolio assessment, adaptive behavior assessment.
Understand the role of formative assessment, response to instruction in relation to planning appropriate instruction.
Become familiar with reporting student progress, data based measurement, and response to intervention.
Administer and interpret formal assessments including a comprehensive standardized achievement battery and diagnostic assessments.
Write and present a formal assessment report.
Write and present an informal assessment report.
Complete a functional behavior assessment report.

sections.title: EDC 822 - Strategies for Teaching Science
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken EDUC 803F .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Explore brain- based learning theory.
Understand and apply research- based instructional models.
Use the principles of science inquiry as a teaching method.
Write a standard- based, measurable learning objective.
Develop the ability to use questioning to encourage higher level thinking for diversified learners.
Plan, implement, and evaluate two five lesson units at two different grade levels (K-grade 3 and grades 4-8) if possible.
In the area of earth science, explain the structure and the process of the earth system and its relationship to the universe.
In the area of life science, explain the structure, function and healthy maintenance of living systems.
In the area of physical science, explain the structure, properties and interactions of energy and matter.
Apply the inquiry process and educational standards of science, pursuant to RSA 193-C:3,III(a), through the use of scientific inquiry.
Apply an awareness of the history and nature of science to an inquiry process and the educational standards of science, pursuant to RSA 193-C:3,III(a), illuminating the history of science.
Enter the three key assignments into the exit portfolio demonstrating attained skills.

sections.title: EDC 823 - Teaching Language Arts and Literacy
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Demonstrate an understanding of the key components and development of language.
Demonstrate an understanding of various theories of emergent literacy and reading development.
Understand the complexity of learning to read and the many factors that affect the process.
Demonstrate knowledge of phonological awareness, synthetic and analytic phonics and apply their knowledge to lessons that they will teach and evaluate.

Demonstrate knowledge of word recognition skills, vocabulary development, fluency development, reading comprehension and the writing process and apply their knowledge to lessons that they will teach and evaluate.
Review study skills and technology as it applies to reading and writing and apply their knowledge to lessons that they will teach and evaluate.
Develop an appreciation for literature and its effective use in teaching reading and writing.
Explore various reading approaches and programs.
Develop an individual program for a student with a learning problem.

Demonstrate the ability, as a member of the educational team, to administer appropriate assessments to identify, plan, teach and evaluate student progress through on-going progress monitoring in the delivery of remedial language arts instruction.

sections.title: EDC 824 - Elementary School Mathematics Methods
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken MATH 803 .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Explore and apply systematic teaching and research based learning strategies.
Explain various mathematical concepts through written explanations, examples, and chapter tests.
Explain and apply accommodations for diversified learners in lesson plans.
Plan, implement, teach, and evaluate mathematics lessons.
Explain why assessment is vital to successful mathematics instruction.
Develop an improvement plan reflecting strengths and weaknesses, and resources to help meet personal goals.
Enter the three key assignments into the exit portfolio demonstrating attained skills.

sections.title: EDC 831 - Aspects of Mathematics Learning
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken MATH 800 .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: [Pivotal Standard] Compare and contrast different learning theories and discuss their appropriateness for diverse students.
[Pivotal Standard] Plan equitable lessons enabling all students to construct new concepts through active participation in mathematical modeling, investigations and problem solving.
Plan lessons incorporating manipulatives, current technologies, and formative assessments.
Provide opportunities for students to use written, oral and other creative expressions to demonstrate their understanding of mathematical concepts to various audiences.
Demonstrate the capacity to appreciate and recognize the value of professional practices which included learning mathematics content independently and collaborative.
Demonstrate knowledge of current state, national and international research, standards, and recommendations regarding teaching of mathematics.
Analyze data to create an action plan improve student learning.
Develop an improvement plan reflecting strengths and weaknesses and resources to help meet personal goals.
Develop an understanding of mathematics instruction through 90 hours (undergraduate)/60 hours (post-baccalaureate) of clinical observation/teaching.

sections.title: EDC 832 - Reading and Writing in the Mathematics Content Area
text: Prerequisite(s): ( EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B- and ( EDC 831 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 752G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Plan and conduct units and lessons appropriate for the grade range which incorporate literacy strategies that assist students in reading and understanding mathematics. Lessons emphasize connections within and between mathematics and other disciplines.

Communicate an understanding of mathematics, including, but not limited to, the ability to demonstrate a capacity to communicate coherently about mathematics and mathematics education in both written and oral ways using appropriate mathematical language and notation. The ability to interpret and explain mathematical ideas through reading mathematics in professional publications, as well as analyze and assess the mathematical thinking and strategies of others. Other Learning Outcomes.

Recognize, explore and develop mathematical connections, including, but not limited to the ability to provide examples of how mathematics is practiced in various fields. Students will build mathematical understanding by identifying and applying connections among mathematical ideas and show how ideas build on one another across grade levels to form a coherent discipline.
Analyze data to create an action plan to improve student learning.
Utilize collaboration and PLCs to improve student learning.
Develop an improvement plan reflecting strengths and weaknesses and resources to help meet personal goals.
Develop an understanding of mathematics instruction through 90 hours of clinical observation/teaching.

sections.title: EDC 833 - Middle Level Mathematics Methods
text: Prerequisite(s): ( EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B- and ( EDC 832 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 753G with a minimum grade of B-.
Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken MATH 803 , MATH 809 .

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Apply Understanding by Design (UBD) to develop and apply mathematics unit plans to enable all students to construct new concepts through active participation in mathematical modeling, investigations, and problem-solving while improving mathematical habits of mind.
Integrate web-based technology into unit plans.
Analyze data from a variety of assessment to create an action plan to improve student learning.
Explore and apply systematic teaching and research-based learning strategies.
Explain various mathematical concepts through written explanations, examples, and formative and summative assessments.
Utilize technology to enhance student learning (advanced level).
Plan, implement, teach, and evaluate mathematics lessons, both face-to-face and online.
Explain why assessment is vital to successful mathematics instruction.
Utilize collaboration and PLCs to improve student learning.
Develop an improvement plan reflecting strengths and weaknesses and resources to help meet personal goals.
Develop an understanding of mathematics instruction through 90 hours of clinical observation/teaching.

Mutual Exclusion: No credit for students who have taken MATH 809 .

sections.title: EDC 844 - Teacher as Researcher
text: Repeat Rule: May be repeated up to unlimited times.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Investigate and compare various research methods used in educational practice.
Apply appropriate research tools to explore a specific problem of practice.
Collect and organize sample data relevant to solving a defined problem of practice.
Analyze data to formulate potential solutions.
Design a data-driven action plan aimed at improving student success.
Demonstrate proficiency in applying APA style guidelines in written work.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Understand and articulate content within the major concepts of Life Sciences Structure and Function: Evidence for common ancestry What drives evolution Population statistics and variation in traits Natural selection, adaptation, and what drives change over time.
Create inquiry learning activities to engage middle or high school students to learn the content.
Brainstorm and develop lesson plans to address common student misconceptions around the content.
Analyze curricula developed by others to determine the effectiveness of lesson plans and anticipate issues that may arise in the classroom.

Create a positive classroom environment as evidenced by clear procedures and mutually respectful relationships.

sections.title: EDC 855 - Culminating Experience for Life Science

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Construct a philosophy of developmentally appropriate educational practice for Life Science that reflects the belief that all children/students can learn and develop to their full potential and shows respect for the gifts and talents of all children/students.

Design developmentally appropriate life science lessons that demonstrate life science content knowledge and connect to state and local curriculum frameworks and guidelines, the community, and the ever changing nature of knowledge.
Design developmentally appropriate inquiry based instruction that supports the cognitive, language, moral, social, emotional, physical, and creative development of children/students.
Design instruction that demonstrates an understanding of diversity of learners and uses a variety of resources including technology.
Create science learning environments that are collaborative, challenging, dynamic, safe, and encourage openness, respect, and caring.

Use formal and informal assessments to continually monitor students’ learning needs, program design, and teaching effectiveness, and demonstrate the ability to communicate the results to children, parents, and colleagues.
Model professionalism in all aspects including: communication, ethics, self-reflection, professional development, and community/school and district involvement.

sections.title: EDC 858 - Introduction to Digital Learning
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: A broad overview of the opportunities and challenges associated with becoming a school-based digital learning specialist.
Developed an understanding of their own attitudes about technology and how they can influence success in the role of digital learning specialist.
Explored the technologies presently available and begin to 'play' with the technologies in a way that demonstrates a level of comfort with the technologies and relevance to the classroom.
The ability to speculate on the future - what will your role be, what new technologies are on the horizon, how might these technologies further enhance our students' learning experiences.
Explored how to design and implement digitally-based learning experiences with multiple and varied formative and summative assessments.

sections.title: EDC 859 - Curricular Theory of Technological Integration
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: How are state and national standards implemented within the curriculum?
What is the relationship between and among curriculum, pedagogy, and assessment?
How can I collaborate with other educators to model, design, and implement technology enhanced learning experiences addressing both technology and content standards?

sections.title: EDC 860 - Pedagogical Practice and Management of Technological Integration
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: How do I model and promote effective management and use of digital tools and resources to support technology rich learning environments?
How do I evaluate, adapt, and reflect on digital tools, resources, and emerging trends by reviewing current research and evidence based innovative practices?
How can I collaborate with other educators to promote innovative and creative thinking using digital tools to engage learners in real-world problem solving?
How do I design and implement digitally based learning experiences with multiple and varied formative and summative assessments?

sections.title: EDC 861 - Meeting the Needs of All Learners Through Technological Integration
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: What is Universal Design for Learning and why is it important to know about?
How do I find out about, evaluate, and support the use of assistive technology for my learners?
How do I model and promote the use of adaptive and assistive technologies and other digital tools and resources to personalize and differentiate activities for all learners?
How do I use technology to support the management and efficiency of my teaching?

sections.title: EDC 863 - Professionalism, Leadership and Administrative Understandings and Practice for Tech. Integration
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Promote and participate in the development an implementation of a shared vision for the comprehensive integration of technology to support learning opportunities for all learners and educators.
Model and promote the effective management and use of digital tools and resources to support a technology rich learning environment.
Evaluate, adapt, and reflect on digital tools, resources, and emerging trends by participating in and contributing to school technology learning communities.
Explore strategies for funding educational technology.

sections.title: EDC 864 - Culminating Teaching Experience: Clinical Synthesis and Implementation of Technological Integration

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Effectively integrate technology with differentiation, rigor, relevance in his or her practice of teaching, learning, and assessment.
Demonstrate proficiency with technological concepts and pedagogy.
Model responsible and safe participation in the digital world.
Develop innovative professional learning opportunities and evaluate the impact on instructional practice and learner competencies.

Promote and participate in the development and implementation of collaborative strategies for the comprehensive integration of technology to support transformational change throughout the instructional environment.

sections.title: EDC 866 - Dynamic Assessment: Complexities of Identification in LD,EBD, and IDD
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Understand the legal and ethical responsibilities of decision-making and the complexity of overlapping conditions in the determination of educational disability.

Understand standards-based accountability, response to instruction/intervention, quantification of test performance, and adapting tests to accommodate students with disabilities and limited English proficiency as part of a changing dynamic assessment process.
Learn how to review a test and assure that definitions and guidelines set forth in the re-authorized IDEA legislation are considered.

Discuss with various qualified examiners the assessment tools and patterns of behavior typically seen in students with a specific learning disability, emotional behavioral disability and with an intellectual or developmental disability.
Understand the critical role of the multidisciplinary team in designing, implementing and interpreting an effective assessment plan.

Use ecological classroom and data-based student observations, formative assessments, and checklists in an objective, analytical approach to gather valid and reliable information for assuring access to the curriculum and making eligibility decisions.

Administer/interpret the appropriate informal and formal academic/behavioral assessments designated by the multidisciplinary team for the determination of a specific learning disability, emotional - behavioral disability and an intellectual or developmental disability.
Learn how to evaluate a test and choose an appropriate functional assessment and adaptive assessment for inclusion in their academic assessment report.

Develop and evaluate an academic report which includes the various required components for a student with a specific learning disability, a student with an emotional disability and a student with an intellectual or developmental disability.

Review and summarize the identification/determination process for a student suspected of having a specific learning disability, an emotional behavioral disability and an intellectual or developmental disability.
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor lesson plans and instructional delivery.
Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of the identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor.

Apply his/her knowledge of the use of formal and informal assessments within the on-going context of formative assessments to monitor the K-12 student progress and the effectiveness of instructional strategies.
Use the K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 867 - Behavioral Supports for Complex Behaviors
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: The teacher candidate will identify 4 students with significant and complex behavior for this project.
The teacher candidate will demonstrate an understanding of the law, policies and ethical principles regarding behavior management, planning and implementation.

The teacher candidate will develop programs that reflect research and evidence based practice. These programs will address: (a) target behaviors (b) functional behavior assessments (c) collect, analyze and interpret formal and informal data (d) individualized reinforcement systems and environmental modifications (e) development of positive behavior intervention plans (f) consistent teacher attitudes and behaviors (g) respectful and beneficial relationships (h) placement options and continuum of services (i) functional classroom designs (j) lease intensive behavior management strategies (k) safe, equitable, positive and support learning environment (l) realistic expectations (m) self-advocacy strategies
The teacher candidate will develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor program and instructional delivery.

The teacher candidate will develop, adapt and evaluate programs to address appropriate learning environments, evidence-based practices to include response to intervention/instruction and formative assessments.

The teacher candidate will analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor K-12 student progress, appropriateness of program and effectiveness of instructional strategies.
The teacher candidate will use K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 868 - Advanced Assistive and Educational Technology
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify a minimum of 4 students with a range of disabilities.
Demonstrate how to use, follow, and apply online discussion boards, publishing, and bookmarking utilities to enrich his/her classroom environment.
Explain, develop and evaluate instructional approaches that use technology relative to the ISTE NETS for Teachers and Students.
Know how to practice, promote, and develop responsible digital citizens.
Evaluate technology tools and software programs.
Identify, recognize and justify the educational value of video to active learning and how video can accommodate various styles of learning.

Develop, implement and evaluate lesson plans in reading, writing, mathematics and social skills. These lesson plans will address evidence-based practices to include response to instruction/intervention, formative assessments and will include: (a) videos (b) podcasts ( c) blogs and wikispaces (d) online social networks (e) PowerPoint (f) CD-ROMs (g) SMART boards (h) live cam feeds (i) virtual field trips (j) assistive technology to support writing (k) assistive technology to support reading (l) assistive technology to enhance communication (m) assistive technology for computer access (n) augmentative or alternative communication

Demonstrate an understanding of how technology supports response to intervention/instruction as an instructional approach that provides multiple tiers of increasingly intensive instructional strategies.

Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of the 4 identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor student progress, evaluate instructional strategies and teaching effectiveness.
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor instructional strategies and instructional delivery.
Use the K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 869 - Advanced Programming for Students with Learning Disabilities
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify a minimum of 4 learning disabled students for this project.
Understand the implications of the history, theories, terminology and definitions related to individuals with learning disabilities.
Understand the implications of the developmental and education needs in developing programs for students with learning disabilities

Understand how to develop, adapt and evaluate programs to address appropriate learning environments, evidence-based instructional strategies to include response to instruction/intervention and formative assessments.
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor program and instructional delivery.

Apply his/her knowledge in the development of programs appropriate for the 4 identified students with learning disabilities, which incorporates evidence-based practice, response to instruction/intervention and formative assessments.
Develop, implement and evaluate lesson plans within the above program that reflect evidence-based instructional strategies and formative assessments.

Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of the identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor K-12 student progress and the appropriateness of the program and effectiveness of the instructional strategies.
Use the K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 870 - Advanced Programming for Emotional/Behavioral Disabilities
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify a minimum of 4 students with emotional and behavioral disabilities for this project.
Will demonstrate an understanding of the implications of the history, theories, terminology and definitions related to students with emotional and behavioral disabilities.
Demonstrate an understanding of the implications of the emotional/behavioral and education needs in developing program for students with emotional and behavioral disabilities.
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor program and instructional delivery.
Develop, adapt and evaluate programs to address appropriate learning environments, evidence-based practices to include response to intervention/instruction and formative assessments.

Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor K-12 student progress, appropriateness of program and effectiveness of instructional strategies.
Use K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 871 - Advanced Programming for Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify a minimum of 4 students with intellectual/developmental disabilities for this project.
Understand the implications of the history, theories, terminology and definitions related to individuals with intellectual/developmental disabilities.
Understand the implications of the developmental and education needs in developing programs for students with intellectual/developmental disabilities

Understand how to develop, adapt and evaluate programs to address appropriate learning environments, evidence-based instructional strategies to include response to instruction/intervention and formative assessments.
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor program and instructional delivery.

Apply his/her knowledge in the development of programs appropriate for the 4 identified students with intellectual/developmental, which incorporates evidence-based practice, response to instruction/intervention and formative assessments.
Develop, implement and evaluate lesson plans within the above program that reflect evidence-based instructional strategies and formative assessments.

Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of the identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor K-09 student progress and the appropriateness of the program and effectiveness of the instructional strategies.
Use the K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion.

sections.title: EDC 872 - Advanced Curriculum, Assessment and Instruction for Students with Learning Disabilities
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify a minimum of 4 students with learning disabilities for this project.

Analyze and understand the implications for research/ evidence-based instructional strategies and formative assessments for the following: a. Characteristics and strategies of students with reading disorders b. Diagnostic skills in planning appropriate instructional strategies. c. Variety of reading approaches for students with learning disabilities. d. Reading interventions for their students. e. Writing process and nature of written language disorders f. Assessment and remediation of written expressive disorders. g. Nature of spelling disorders h. Spelling interventions. i. Nature of handwriting disorders. j. Remediation of handwriting disorders. k. Social side of learning disabilities l. Behavior intervention plans. m. Interventions to address the social aspects of LD in their classroom. n. Characteristics of students with LD in mathematics. o. Instruction of mathematics to students with LD.
Demonstrate an understanding of response to intervention/instruction as an instructional approach that provides multiple tiers of increasingly intensive instructional strategies.
Have opportunities to practice the application of basic progress monitoring concepts within the response to intervention (RTI) approach.

Develop and implement lesson plans in reading, writing and mathematics for the 4 identified students. These lesson plans will reflect the application of basic progress monitoring within the response to intervention (RTI) approach.

Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of the 4 identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor student progress, evaluate instructional strategies and teaching effectiveness.
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor instructional strategies and instructional delivery.
Use the K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 873 - Advanced Curriculum, Assessment and Instruction for Emotional/Behavioral Disabilities
text: Prerequisite(s): ( EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B- and ( EDC 866 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 736G with a minimum grade of B- and ( EDC 867 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 737G with a minimum grade of B- and ( EDC 868 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 738G with a minimum grade of B- and ( EDC 870 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 741G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify a minimum of 4 students with emotional and behavioral disabilities for this project.

Analyze, develop and adapt research/evidence-based instructional strategies and formative assessments specific to the education needs of students with emotional/behavioral disabilities: a. development and characteristics b. individual learning differences c. instructional strategies d. learning environments and social interactions e. language f. instructional planning g. informal and formal assessments h. partners i. resources
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor program and instructional delivery.

Develop, implement and evaluate lesson plans in reading, writing, mathematics and social skills for the 4 identified students. These lesson plans will reflect the application of progress monitoring within the response to intervention/instruction approach.

Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor K-12 student progress, appropriateness of program and effectiveness of instructional strategies.
Use K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 874 - Advanced Curriculum, Assessment and Instruction for Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify a minimum of 4 students with intellectual/developmental disabilities for this project.

Analyze and understand the implications for research/ evidence-based instructional strategies and formative assessments for the following: a. development and characteristics b. individual learning differences c. instructional strategies d. learning environments and social interactions e. language f. instructional planning g. informal and formal assessment h. partners i. resources
Demonstrate an understanding of response to intervention/instruction as an instructional approach that provides multiple tiers of increasingly intensive instructional strategies.
Have opportunities to practice the application of basic progress monitoring concepts within the response to intervention (RTI) approach.

Develop, implement and evaluate lesson plans in reading, writing, mathematics and social skills for the 4 identified students. These lesson plans will reflect the application of basic progress monitoring within the response to intervention (RTI) approach.

Analyze the biweekly formative assessment data of the 4 identified students, and discuss the data results with the district mentor and faculty advisor to monitor student progress, evaluate instructional strategies and teaching effectiveness.
Develop skills to be an effective team member within learning communities to support K-12 student progress, monitor instructional strategies and instructional delivery.
Use the K-12 student achievement data as the primary evidence of successful completion of course objectives.

sections.title: EDC 875 - Foundations of Language and Literacy Development
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Demonstrate an understanding of the inter-relationships between language, cognitive and social development and literacy development.
Demonstrate and understanding of how students develop oral language, phonological awareness, word recognition, vocabulary, fluency and comprehension.
Demonstrate an understanding the reciprocal nature of reading and writing and strategies for developing written expression.
Develop a Staff Development Portfolio with specific strategies and techniques for the critical reading components which can be used before during and after reading.
Explore approach and methods for reading instruction and programming.
Explore guidelines for choosing literature and will analyze a basal and or literature based reading series in relation to the National Reading Panel recommendations.
Design a framework for a balanced literacy program for grades K-2, 3-5 and 6-8 which will include an inquiry based approach and critical components.
Form a personal philosophy of reading instruction and develop a three -year action plan for personal growth.
Enter artifacts into the portfolio demonstrating attained skills.

sections.title: EDC 876 - Reading and Writing Disabilities: Assessment and Instruction
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Identify the correlates of reading disabilities for two case study students at different levels of reading development.
Review and select appropriate formal and informal reading assessments.
Complete two case study assessments of students with reading disabilities at different grade levels.
Develop an intervention plan and identify appropriate goals and objectives in relation to NH language arts curriculum frameworks and recent reading research.
Develop and implement appropriate reading strategies to address the goals of each case study students, including strategies for phonemic awareness, phonics, vocabulary, fluency and comprehension.
Use formal and informal measures and explore a variety of reading techniques to develop an assessment-instruction portfolio.
Review high stakes testing and develop a plan for recording literacy progress to inform instruction for all students.
Self-reflect on their ability to plan assessments, design and implement instruction and effectively report results to parents and peers.

sections.title: EDC 877 - Content Area Literacy
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Review Reports from the National Reading Panel, Reading Next, Writing Next and read many other researched- based reports about current adolescent literacy.
Develop an understanding of the complexities and difficulties of content area reading and various methods to evaluate the readability of texts.
Explore strategic thinking and ways to scaffold instruction to meet the needs of struggling and English Language Learning students.
Learn strategies for teaching vocabulary, comprehension, writing and study skills and share these strategies with other professionals.
Develop lessons/workshops to incorporate strategies before reading, during reading and after reading in content area materials.
Explore writing and its interrelationship and role in developing literacy.
Keep a journal to record initial reactions and changing perceptions to key statements and reflect on their journaling.
Explore the development of thematic units and the use trade books, multiple texts and electronic texts to enhance content literacy and thematic units.
Review current practice at their school and offer suggestions based on research supported best practice for improving literacy instruction.
Develop, present and evaluate staff development presentations to expand the literacy skills and knowledge of professional and paraprofessional staff.

sections.title: EDC 878 - Developing Literate Students, K-12
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Enter artifacts into the portfolio demonstrating attained skills.
Develop an appreciation for what is scientifically based research and how to use research and reason to make curricular and instructional decisions.

Summarize recent research findings about the reading process including the National Reading Panel's recommendations in each of the following areas: phonemic awareness, phonics, fluency, comprehension of vocabulary and text.
Analyze an elementary, middle, or high school literacy program in relation to effective characteristics and practices.
Complete the Reflection of Student Work (RASW) and link to instruction.

sections.title: EDC 879 - Role of the Reading and Writing Specialist I - Practicum
text: Prerequisite(s): ( EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B-) and ( EDC 875 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 730G with a minimum grade of B-) and ( EDC 876 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 712G with a minimum grade of B-) and ( EDC 877 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 713G with a minimum grade of B-).

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Leadership: a. Establish a school-based literacy team and develop a vision statement that is consistent with state and national reading and language arts standards b. Review high stakes testing and develop a comprehensive learner profile to monitor individual student progress and school reading data. c. Assess a school's literacy needs and work with the team to create a 2-year professional development plan based on the assessment. d. Enter artifacts into the portfolio demonstrating attained skills.

Professional Development and Capacity Building: a. Develop and conduct literacy workshops as suggested in the literacy team's professional development plan. b. Develop an appreciation form what is scientifically based research and how to use research and reason to make curricular and instructional decisions c. Summarize recent research findings about the reading process including the National Reading Panel's recommendations in each of the following areas: phonemic awareness, phonics, fluency, comprehension of vocabulary and text

Program Development and Management: a. Analyze an elementary or middle/ adolescent literacy program in relation to effective characteristics and practices b. Identify appropriate instructional models, methods, contexts, routines and strategies to design a well balanced reading program. c. Research the philosophical basis of handwriting and keyboarding, the developmental stages and current programs designed to teach handwriting and keyboarding skills for inclusion in your program development if this aspect falls under your responsibility d. Develop the initial components for a well- balanced elementary literacy program which will be expanded on in the future based on research and informed practice e. Develop the initial components for a well- balanced adolescent literacy program which will be expanded on in the future based on research and informed practice

sections.title: EDC 880 - Role of the Reading and Writing Specialist II - Practicum
text: Prerequisite(s): ( EDC 800 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 700G with a minimum grade of B- and ( EDC 879 with a minimum grade of B- or EDU 711G with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Improving leadership, coordination, and communication, which are necessary components for carrying out an effective school/district reading program.
Examining assessment tools and data to inform instructional decisions in reading.

Addressing access to print issues within their school/district to increase students opportunities for success in reading(e.g., programs to increase access to print through libraries, technology, summer events, tutorials, after-school activities, parent education, family literacy).
Exploring scientifically based- research and using research and reason to make curricular and instructional decisions.
Exploring grant writing to strengthen professional development or promote school-community literacy.
Addressing professional development within their school/district to provide relevant, ongoing, direct instruction and embedded experiences tied to student assessment data and needs.
Planning and preparing students for high stakes testing situations to appropriately reflect student skills and competencies.

Developing a technical assistance/literacy coach model for training and on-going professional development. Serve as a cognitive coach for teacher(s) and evaluate and revise the program for maximum results.
Examining curriculum, reading programs and materials designed to inform instructional decisions in reading.
Identifying the use of instructional contexts, routines, and strategies designed to meet the reading needs of all students.
Developing a system for assessment and data collection.
Developing a system for communicating and collaborating with the classroom teachers to support and improve literacy.

Addressing the reading needs of special populations within their school/district(e.g., special education, African-American, ELL, migrant, homeless, transient, socioeconomic status, gifted, neglected).
Prepare guidelines and a system for the selection of instructional materials for the school and effective budgeting.

Discuss the philosophical basis of handwriting and keyboarding, the developmental stages and current programs designed to teach handwriting and keyboarding skills for inclusion in your program development if this aspect falls under your responsibility.

sections.title: EDC 885 - Culminating Teaching Experience and Seminar

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Construct a philosophy of developmentally appropriate educational practice that reflects the belief that all children/students can learn and develop to their full potential, and shows respect for the gifts and talents of all children/students.

Design developmentally appropriate practice and lesson plans that demonstrate their knowledge of the content they teach; and are able to connect to state and local curriculum frameworks and guidelines, the community and the ever changing nature of knowledge.
Design developmentally appropriate practices and instruction that supports the cognitive, language, moral, social, emotional, physical and creative development of children/students.
Design instruction that demonstrates an understanding of diversity of learners and uses a variety of resources including technology.
Create learning environments that are collaborative, challenging, dynamic, safe, and encourage openness, respect and caring.

Use formal and informal assessments to continually monitor children's/student's learning needs, program design and teaching effectiveness, and have the ability to communicate the results to children, parents and colleagues.
Model professionalism in all aspects including: communication, ethics, self-reflection, professional development and community/school and district involvement.
Communicate the TCAP expectations to the faculty members of their clinical site.
Use video in a self-reflection process.
Submit a completed TCAP document detailing the process and outcome of the culminating teaching experience.
Complete the Exit Survey: https://www/surveymonkey.com/s/8TPST83

sections.title: EDC 885B - Culminating Teaching Experience and Seminar for Already Certified Teachers

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Construct a philosophy of developmentally appropriate educational practice that reflects the belief that all children/students can learn and develop to their full potential, and shows respect for the gifts and talents of all children/students in the certification area of focus. This philosophy should include explicit connections to professional literature and resources.

Design developmentally appropriate practice and lesson plans that demonstrate their knowledge of the content they teach; and are able to connect to state and local curriculum frameworks and guidelines, the community, and the ever changing nature of knowledge.

Design developmentally appropriate practices and instruction that supports the cognitive, language, moral, social, emotional, physical, and creative development of children/students and demonstrates an understanding of diversity of learners using a variety of resources including technology.
Create learning environments that are collaborative, challenging, dynamic, safe, and encourage openness, respect and caring.

Use formal and informal assessments to continually monitor children's/student's learning needs, program design, and teaching effectiveness, and have the ability to communicate the results to children, parents and colleagues.
Model professionalism in all aspects including: communication, ethics, self-reflection, professional development, and community/school and district involvement.
Communicate the TCAP expectations to the faculty members of their clinical site.
Complete a comprehensive TCAP document detailing the process and outcome of the culminating teaching experience.
Create a final Professional Portfolio and summary of clinical hours demonstrating teaching philosophy and experiences.

sections.title: EDC 894 - Capstone Project I: Leadership Essentials to Strategically Think, Plan, Implement & Evaluate

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Consider and ask questions about the MSIL's program requirements, philosophy, and operation.
Identify an experienced in-school mentor to support site-based action research.
Personally reflect on the embodiment of the Professional Standards for Educational Leaders (NPBEA, 2015).
Apply a distributive leadership model to various PK-12 school circumstances and discuss implications for student learning.

sections.title: EDC 895 - Leadership Essentials: Evaluation of Teaching and Learning
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 892 with a minimum grade of B- or EDC 894 with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Critique current trends in the K-12 system, that promote best practices in teacher evaluation and school leadership.
Use data to justify a proposed action research project that addresses a site-based problem of practice.
Develop and articulate an action research thesis, research question.

sections.title: EDC 896 - Leadership Essentials to Develop and Support a Professional Culture
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 892 with a minimum grade of B- or EDC 894 with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Compare and contrast approaches to create, and sustain a school culture of professional development, collaboration and reflective practice.
Apply adult learning theory to a school professional development setting.
Create a site-based action research proposal that Integrates specific components of adult learning theory and addresses a data driven, on-site problem of practice.

sections.title: EDC 897 - Capstone Project II: Leadership Essentials to Strategically Think, Plan, Implement, & Evaluate
text: Prerequisite(s): EDC 892 with a minimum grade of B- or EDC 894 with a minimum grade of B-.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Design, schedule, and implement a site-based action research project.
Gather and analyze data regarding the effectiveness of specific pedagogical strategies implemented during an on-site action research project.
Create a summary paper and corresponding media presentation of the context, need, procedure, participants, findings, and reflections of a completed on-site action research project.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Writing Process and Self-Reflection (a) Enact the various stages of the writing process to their own writing, (b) Develop effective strategies for generating ideas, (c) Utilize peer and instructor feedback to revise their writing for impact, (d) Reflect critically on their own writing processes.

Genre Study and Pedagogical Knowledge (a) Develop a better understanding a familiarity as a writer of a specific genre (e.g., poetry, narrative, memoir, argumentative – depending on the instructor) to understand its conventions, purposes, and audience expectations, (b) Utilize technology or other tools to support the writing process, (c) Learn ways of providing feedback and encouraging student writers.

Fostering a Writing Community (a) Create a supportive and collaborative learning environment that encourages risk-taking and experimentation in writing, (b) Provide constructive feedback to peers in a respectful and helpful manner, (c) Participate actively in class discussions and workshops.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Describe the mechanisms of maintenance and acquisition of genetic material in bacteria.
Analyze model genetic systems and apply mechanisms to novel or non-model systems.
Use bioinformatics tools to understand genome structure, function and evolution.
Apply genetic techniques to design experiments to study gene and cell functions.
Master various recombinant DNA and molecular genetics techniques, perform data analysis and interpret data.
Critically review and master scientific writing for communication of research.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Apply the key theories, concepts, definitions, and terminology of Unoccupied Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Technologies.
Have a strong knowledge of the types and uses of UAVs and UAV Sensor Systems across multiple disciplines.
Discuss topics on good use practices of UAV Remote Sensing technologies.
Utilize UAV flight planning, Image Processing, and GIS software for UAV remote sensing purposes.
Become familiar with hands-on UAV operations and remotely sensed areal data collection.
Understand how to register UAV acquired imagery to real world coordinates using ground control points and Global Positioning System (GPS) technologies.
Have the ability to create products such as digital elevation models, land-cover classifications, and final map products from UAV derived imagery.
Build and implement a full UAV data collection, image processing, and mapping workflow from start to finish.

sections.title: HLTC 800 - Health Care Delivery and Innovations

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Analyze direct health care delivery structures and processes within and across health care settings and explores their impact within the health care systems.
Explore and evaluate health care systems at micro and macro levels and the connections between the various levels of analysis.
Identify and implement the knowledge, skills, and tools that contribute to managing cutting edge delivery strategy and processes.
Understand the importance of health care policy-making as it related to health care delivery system.
Implement systems thinking and processes identify, engage and manage innovative organizational change that is relevant to health care setting.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Analyze the impact of recent health care reform and the resulting critical need for closer clinical and financial integration.
Apply business and economic principles and practices to revenue cycle processes including private and government payers, billing compliance, audits, charity care and bad debt.
Review budgeting processes and financial reporting that is unique to the health care industry.
Appraise the ways financial and clinical decisions impact daily operations, as well as the financial health of the organization.
Evaluate the ways health care executives are addressing the current challenges in the financing of health care delivery.
Apply communication strategies to engage in dialogue with the finance team and stakeholders.

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Analyze how policies influence the structure and financing of health care and population health outcomes.
Engage in the evaluation of current issues in health care insurance coverage, access and regulation specific to population health outcomes, socioeconomic challenges and current barriers.
Examine the effect of legal and regulatory processes on interprofessional practice, health care delivery, and patient outcomes.
Interpret research, bringing the value of an interprofessional, collaborative perspective, for policy makers and stakeholders.
Advocate for policies specifically to the impact they have to improve health.

sections.title: HLTC 810 - Health Care Quality and Safety

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Analyze information about quality initiatives and the unique interprofessional roles required to sustain improvements and improve population health outcomes.
Compare and contrast strengths and weakness of quality improvement models.

Promote a professional environment that includes accountability and high-level communication skills when involved in peer review, advocacy for patients and families, reporting of errors, and professional writing.
Plan, implement and evaluate evidence based quality improvement methods to promote culturally responsive, safe, timely, effective, efficient, equitable, and patient-centered care.

sections.title: HLTC 811 - Health Care Technology and Informatics

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Perform rigorous critique of evidence derived from databases to generate meaningful evidence-based decision-making.
Analyze current and emerging technologies specific to health care environments, patient education, safety, cost effectiveness and improvement of health outcomes.
Evaluate outcome data using current communication technologies, information systems, and statistical principles to collaboratively develop strategies to reduce risks and improve health outcomes.
Promote policies that incorporate ethical principles and standards for the use of health and information technologies.
Provide oversight and guidance in the integration of technologies to document patient care and improve patient outcomes.
Integrate ethical principles in the use of technology in the areas of documentation of care and outcomes, as well as in the application to health education.

sections.title: HLTC 850 - Health Care Management Integrative Capstone

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Analyze the organizational, economic, political, and legal components of health care delivery systems.
Evaluate ethical issues relevant to the policies, practices, and management of health care systems.
Synthesize and integrate knowledge of current health care management policies, practices, and theory.
Develop and communicate design solutions that guide a community of interest within health care to change and adapt to future challenges.
Apply functional knowledge of financial management within the health care setting.
Plan and formulate a solution to an identified need within a health care setting that includes recommendation(s).

subsections.title: View Course Learning Outcomes
lists: Articulate the scope and value of qualitative methodologies in health outcomes research.
Develop meaningful and focused qualitative research questions pertinent to behavioral health,\\nfactors influencing health interventions, and effectiveness of the interventions.
Generate a conceptual model that exemplifies the researchable questions and operationalize\\nthe research questions and conceptual models for outcomes research analyses.
Compare and contrast the application of qualitative and quantitative study designs for\\nconducting health outcomes research.
Describe and apply major qualitative traditions and analytical techniques pertinent to health\\noutcomes research.
Identify and critique sources of qualitative data for health outcomes research.
Apply scientific principles to the analysis of qualitative data and the visual presentation of\\nhealth outcomes data.
